Scenario 1

Capt X and Capt Y had a busy weekend ahead of them. They needed to be at the range early the next morning, and they had just finished driving to the support base and their minivan was full of supplies, including 20kg of .22 ammunition.

 

To make their departure the next morning easier, they decided to park their van close to the house, lock the doors and leave it packed.

 

Sometime overnight their van was broken into and the ammunition was stolen. The newspaper reported the theft and brought attention to the Capt’s membership in the CAF and their involvement with cadets.   In the article, a police spokesperson surmised that the ammunition would probably be sold for drug money or may be used illegally.

 

What were the consequences of this incident and can Capt X or Capt Y be held liable?

Some of the consequences could be:

 

•        Negative media for the Cadet program

•        Capt X and Capt Y could be charged for improper storage of ammunition (CATO 14-41)

•        Financial loss for the CAF (cost of the ammunition)

•        Postponement or cancellation of a planned activity

•        Loss of reputation of Capt X, Capt Y and perhaps the CIC

•        A member who is charged with unsafe handling or transportation of ammunition may not be employed for similar tasks in the future.
